etymologies: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘a person who lets something drop’); dropper (sense 1) is first recorded in the late 19th century

definitions: a short glass tube with a rubber bulb at one end and a tiny hole at the other, for measuring out drops of medicine or other liquids

examples.text: oils sold in bottles with a rubber-tipped dropper

shortDefinitions: short glass tube with rubber bulb at one end and tiny hole at other, for measuring out drops of medicine

definitions: a subsidiary line or loop of filament attached to a main line or leader
shortDefinitions: subsidiary line or loop of filament attached to main line or leader
